title: How to Avoid Spilling

steps.headline: Walk slowly.
steps.description: Scientists have found that a cup of coffee just happens to be the right size to set up waves when we walk. The faster one walks, the quicker and stronger the waves. You know what happens next—flying coffee! By walking slower, the sympathetic resonances are decreased, and your drink stays where it belongs.

steps.headline: Look at your drink.
steps.description: Keep your eye on your drink, not your feet. This not only helps you walk slower, by focusing on your drink you are constantly aware and making adjustments for any sloshing that's going on.

steps.headline: Don't rush.
steps.description: The slower you start moving, the less the drink in your cup will start sloshing. By not dashing from here to there, you make it easier to keep your drink in the cup, and not on the ground. Be alert for others in the area, since a bump or even a close call can result in an accident.

steps.headline: Hold the cup or plate with both hands.
steps.description: This makes it easier to control. Make several trips instead of trying to carry a plate in one hand and a glass in the other.

steps.headline: Don't carry drinks on an empty stomach.
steps.description: Have a snack, or drink some juice and eat some fruit if you are going to an event where you're to have food. Holding anything on an empty stomach can be extra difficult.

steps.headline: Know which hand is steady and for what things.
steps.description: If you're using one hand to carry a beverage, use your steady hand. If you're using two hands, use the steady hand to control the sloshing, and the other hand as support.

steps.headline: Know your limits.
steps.description: Soup is nearly impossible to carry on a cafeteria tray if you have a hand tremor. Avoid it or soak a piece of bread in it.

steps.headline: Carry a cafeteria tray with one forearm under the tray.
steps.description: Your forearm can be much steadier than your hands. Also, either avoid putting tall drinks on a cafeteria tray or hold both the tray and the drink with one of your hands.
